required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on December 16, 2021
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Virtual Reality Analgesia for Brief Thermal Pain
clinical_study.official_title: Virtual Reality Analgesia for Brief Thermal Pain

brief_summary.textblock: Using immersive virtual reality as a form of pain distraction during a brief "painful but tolerable" temperature.

detailed_description.textblock:
This study will use Quantitative Sensory Testing (computer-controlled brief 10 second thermal pain stimuli) in healthy college students.
The primary aim is to conduct a randomized, controlled study with healthy volunteers to explore whether interacting with virtual objects in VR via a highly immersive VR system makes VR significantly more effective/powerful compared to a less immersive VR system, vs. No VR, for reducing pain during quantitative sensory testing.

study_design_info.intervention_model_description: A between-groups design will be used to test the primary hypothesis. A Mixed Model repeated measures ANOVA or non-parametric tests if appropriate will be conducted on worst pain ratings. During the 10 second treatment stimulus, Group 1 will receive No VR, Group 2 will receive Low Tech VR, and Group 3 will receive High Tech VR.
study_design_info.masking_description: Some of the instructions will be presented by the investigators to the participants via a computer.avatar research assistant (investigator) who remains blind to the participants treatment group. Although no deception is involved, participants who receive VR will remain unaware of the immersiveness of the VR systems they are receiving for their primary treatment.

primary_outcome.measure: Worst pain, baseline, participant's rating of "worst pain" during baseline measure
primary_outcome.time_frame: Immediately after a single 10 second test (no more than 10 minutes before the subsequent test stiim)
primary_outcome.description: Baseline, Worst pain rating using a single graphic rating scale, 0 = no pain, 10 = excruciating pain

primary_outcome.measure: participant's rating of "worst pain" during test phase
primary_outcome.time_frame: Immediately after each single 10 second test stimulus (< 10 minutes after baseline pain rating)
primary_outcome.description: Test phase, Worst pain rating using a single graphic rating scale, 0 = no pain, 10 = excruciating pain

secondary_outcome.measure: Baseline, participants rating of "time spent thinking about pain"
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Immediately after a single 10 second test (no more than 10 minutes before the subsequent test stiim)
secondary_outcome.description: Baseline Time thinking, Single a single graphic rating scale, 0 = none of the time, 10 = all of the time

secondary_outcome.measure: Test Phase, participants rating of "time spent thinking about pain" during test phase
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Immediately after each single 10 second test stimulus (< 10 minutes after baseline pain rating)
secondary_outcome.description: Test phase, Time rating, using a single graphic rating scale, 0 = none of the time, 10 = all of the time

secondary_outcome.time_frame: Immediately after a single 10 second test (no more than 10 minutes before the subsequent test stiim)
secondary_outcome.description: Baseline, Unpleasant rating, using single graphic rating scale, 0 = not unpleasant at all, 10 = excruciatingly unpleasant

secondary_outcome.measure: Test phase, participants rating of "pain unpleasantness" during test phase
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Immediately after each single 10 second test stimulus (< 10 minutes after baseline pain rating)
secondary_outcome.description: Test phase, pain unpleasantness, 0 = not unpleasant at all, 10 = excruciatingly unpleasant

secondary_outcome.measure: Baseline, participants rating of "Fun" during baseline
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Immediately after a single 10 second test (no more than 10 minutes before the subsequent test stiim)
secondary_outcome.description: Baseline fun, 0 = no fun at all, 10 = extremely fun

secondary_outcome.measure: Test Phase, participants ratings of "Fun" during test phase
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Immediately after each single 10 second test stimulus (< 10 minutes after baseline fun rating)
secondary_outcome.description: Test phase fun, 0 = no fun at all, 10 = extremely fun

arm_group.description: No VR during a 10 sec baseline pain stimulus, and No VR again during the 10 second test stimulus (at a painful but tolerable temperature individualized and approved by the patient earlier in the study).
No VR during a 10 sec baseline pain stimulus, and Low Tech VR during the 10 second test stimulus
No VR during a 10 sec baseline pain stimulus, and High Tech VR during the 10 second test stimulus

intervention.description: participants interact with a computer generated world

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Currently enrolled in a course at the University of Washington Psychology Dept., participating in the UW Psychology subject pool
- Able to read, write and comprehend English
- Able to complete study measures
- Willing to follow our UW approved instructions
- 18 years of age or older
- Currently enrolled in a course at the University of Washington Psychology Dept., participating in the UW Psychology subject pool
- Able to read, write and comprehend English
- Able to complete study measures
- Willing to follow our UW approved instructions
- 18 years of age or older The following temporary inclusion/exclusion criterion will exist only as long as required or appropriate for COVID pandemic conditions.
COVID-19 precautions. Vaccinated: Individuals are considered fully vaccinated 2 weeks after the second dose in a 2-dose series (e.g., Pfizer or Moderna) or 2 weeks after a single-dose vaccine (e.g., Johnson & Johnson).
All students and researchers must wear masks at all times during the study, and participants and researchers must provide proof of full vaccination for full participation.
If participants do not have proof of vaccination or are unvaccinated, they are still free to sign up for the study. They are invited. They can still earn the extra credit by reading educational materials, in person, during their scheduled time slot. If unvaccinated, or if they have no proof of vaccination, we request that students provide proof of a negative COVID-19 test from the UW test site at the faculty lounge, dated within 24 hours of the study (non-vaccinated students need a recent negative COVID-19 test from the UW before participating in the non-VR educational materials option.
-
Exclusion Criteria:
- People how have already previously participated in this same study (e.g., last quarter) are not eligible to participate again.
- Not enrolled in a course at the University of Washington Psychology Dept., participating in the UW Psychology subject pool
- Not be able to read, write and comprehend English
- Younger than 18 years of age.
- Not capable of completing measures
- Not capable of indicating pain intensity,
- Not capable of filling out study measures,
- Extreme susceptibility to motion sickness,
- Seizure history,
- Unusual sensitivity or lack of sensitivity to pain,
- Sensitive skin,
- Sensitive feet
- Migraines
- Diabetes
The following temporary inclusion/exclusion criterion will exist only as long as required or appropriate for COVID pandemic conditions.
COVID-19 precautions. Vaccinated: Individuals are considered fully vaccinated 2 weeks after the second dose in a 2-dose series (e.g., Pfizer or Moderna) or 2 weeks after a single-dose vaccine (e.g., Johnson & Johnson).
All students and researchers must wear masks at all times during the study, and participants and researchers must provide proof of full vaccination for full participation.
If participants do not have proof of vaccination or are unvaccinated, they are still free to sign up for the study. They are invited. They can still earn the extra credit by reading educational materials, in person, during their scheduled time slot. If unvaccinated, or if they have no proof of vaccination, we request that students provide proof of a negative COVID-19 test from the UW test site at the faculty lounge, dated within 24 hours of the study.

facility.name: University of Washington (only Psych students eligible, public not eligible for participation)

reference.citation: Al-Ghamdi NA, Meyer WJ 3rd, Atzori B, Alhalabi W, Seibel CC, Ullman D, Hoffman HG. Virtual Reality Analgesia With Interactive Eye Tracking During Brief Thermal Pain Stimuli: A Randomized Controlled Trial (Crossover Design). Front Hum Neurosci. 2020 Jan 23;13:467. doi: 10.3389/fnhum.2019.00467. eCollection 2019.

patient_data.ipd_description: Aggregated data will be provided upon request on a case by case basis (e.g., for meta-analyses).
